Just for the record, I think the professor confused these two spacecraft. Mars Observer was the one that 'crashed,' in 1993. (More precisely, it broke down and failed to achieve Mars orbit.) Mars Global Surveyor, launched in 1996, had a long and successful mission, until it was ended in its third mission extension by operator error. Both carried MOLA instruments. On the first, which never returned any data, this stood for Mars Observer Laser Altimeter. NASA re-acronymned the second as Mars Orbiter Laser Altimeter.

Input.threadtitle: if Mars has no plate tectonics then why are those three volcanoes in the Tharsis region evenly spaced on a straight line?
Input.posts:
Stupid question: How come they're on such a straight line? Is this just a coincidence? On Earth I'd explain it through moving tectonic plates (like Mike also said in the video, with the example of Hawaii), but on Mars that isn't the reason. Or did Mars use to have plate tectonics when it was younger and had more liquid water? But then wouldn't there be more such volcanoes in the hypothetical ocean, i.e. Amazonian region? In case it's not obvious to you what I'm talking about, here's a map section showing these three volcanoes .

But I'd still be curious to hear whether you have any theories on what could have caused this alignment.

Crack, lotsa impact-energy that made mars partly liquid, while cooling down again from the outside inwards maybe a few vulcano's were born as part of the process?

Mars doesn't have an atmosphere because it doesn't have a magnetic field because there is no molten core because there are no plate tectonics because there's no flowing water. But there was flowimg watwr and plate tectonics so where did it all go? What do we think happened and more importantly can it happen here on Earth?

But that is not so difficult. Mars cooled down after it formed as all planets did. Mars is small and because of that lost its magnetic field (can't have a rotating iron core in solid rock which is cooled down from previous lava). And as result the Sun was able to blast its atmosphere away. Mars's small size was a negative in this case too....less gravity available to hold on to its atmosphere. And than plate tectonics stopped too, water disappeared or got frozen.... You sum it up pretty good. But its all the result of small size and cooling down. I believe it will happen on Earth too sooner or later. Its cooling too but much slower. Maybe our Sun runs out of gas faster as Earth runs out of internal heat. I agree.....a wrap up video (or pdf) at the end of every week would be very helpfull

Can I propose some refinements to the logic flow given by Andrea? Mars doesn't have much atmosphere because it doesn't have a magnetic field to protect it from sputtering. (And also because the escape velocity of Mars is low.) Mars doesn't have a magnetic field because the conducting core doesn't convect. The core doesn't convect because there is no plate tectonics - there is a static lid and no temperature gradient as described in lecture 1.21. There is no plate tectonics because there is no liquid water to act as a lubricant. There is no liquid water because the temperature regime and atmospheric pressure are too low. Whoops! I'm back where I started. Let's terraform Mars and start all over again. ;-) Rodney
